items.title: Texas Supreme Court Rules on Produced Water Ownership
items.description: Texas is awash in billions of gallons of produced water, the wastewater brought to the surface in oil and gas drilling and fracking.  Most produced water is injected into disposal wells. items.title: Latest GOP Provisions in Budget Bill Seek to Crush Renewable Energy
items.description: Far from the front lines of the climate crisis, 100 men and women in air-conditioned offices, 61 of them millionaires, are making decisions that could increase United States carbon dioxide emissions, and the warming of the climate they are driving, for decades to come. items.title: Part of the New York City Park Experience: Joining the War on Invasives
items.description: It’s on the walls of brownstones and train stations and in New York City parks. And it isn’t mold—it’s English Ivy.  A non-native plant, English Ivy (Hedera helix) outcompetes native flora and fauna for vital resources, degrades habitats and disrupts delicate ecosystems. Recognizing the threat, the Prospect Park Alliance hosted an invasive species removal event […]

items.title: Helping Bees Find New Homes Across New York City, From Fresh Kills to Street Planters
items.description: Tucked away in Brooklyn’s Calvert Vaux Park near Coney Island, one of the largest bee habitats in the city was once a rose garden, full of ornamental “Knock Out roses,” which are not native to the region. Now, replanted with mountain mint, coneflowers and milkweed, a pollinator garden attracts a variety of bees and birds […]

items.description: ASHEBORO, N.C.—Boxy, gunmetal gray buildings loom over a labyrinth of ducts and tubes and catwalks, beyond which 100 train cars loll on their tracks. Smokestacks wait to exhale.
